deliberation: I examined whether the coming from Edom/Bozrah is literal geography or symbolic, and whether the clothed/majestic warrior is literal or an image of YHWH. I concluded that the verse presents a divine warrior metaphor and also uses Edom/Bozrah metonymically for hostile nations.

instances.hebrew_text: מִי־זֶה בָּא מֵאֱדוֹם חֲמוּץ בְּגָדִים מִבׇּצְרָה זֶה הָדוּר בִּלְבוּשׁוֹ צֹעֶה בְּרֹב כֹּחוֹ
instances.english_text: Who is this coming from Edom, in crimsoned garments from Bozrah—who is this, majestic in attire, pressing forward with great might?
vehicle: a human warrior returning from battle with blood-stained garments
ground: victory, power, and having just executed judgment
shared qualities between warrior and deity
instances.explanation: YHWH is portrayed as a majestic warrior returning from battle with bloodied clothing, using human battle imagery to communicate divine judgment and salvation.

instances.english_text: from Edom ... from Bozrah
target: hostile nations/opponents of YHWH and Israel
vehicle: Edom and its chief city Bozrah
ground: Edom’s traditional role as an arch-enemy symbolizes all hostile powers
posture: prophetic characterization of the enemies under judgment
instances.explanation: Edom and Bozrah function as metonymy for the broader hostile world powers that YHWH has just judged.

deliberation: I looked for explicit comparison markers (כְּ) and for any hyperbolic or symbolic use of color. The main device is a simile comparing the stained garments to those of a grape-treader.

instances.english_text: Your garments [are] like those of someone who treads grapes in the winepress
target: the appearance of YHWH’s garments after judgment
vehicle: a grape-treader spattered with juice in a winepress
ground: deep red staining and splattering from violent treading
posture: questioning shock at the bloody-looking garments
instances.explanation: The red-stained garments are compared to those of a person trampling grapes, highlighting the visual effect of blood-like splatter from divine judgment.

deliberation: I checked whether the winepress language is literal or an image for judgment. The entire verse extends the winepress metaphor: peoples are treated as grapes whose ‘juice’ (blood) spatters the divine warrior.

instances.hebrew_text: פּוּרָה דָּרַכְתִּי לְבַדִּי ... וְאֶדְרְכֵם בְּאַפִּי וְאֶרְמְסֵם בַּחֲמָתִי וְיֵז נִצְחָם עַל־בְּגָדַי וְכׇל־מַלְבּוּשַׁי אֶגְאָלְתִּי
instances.english_text: I trod out a vintage alone ... I trod them down in My anger, trampled them in My rage; their life-blood bespattered My garments, and all My clothing was stained.
target: YHWH’s act of judging the nations
vehicle: treading grapes in a winepress, with juice splattering the presser
ground: crushing, total overpowering, and the resulting red liquid covering the presser
posture: self-presentation as a solitary, resolute judge
instances.explanation: The nations are metaphorically treated as grapes in a winepress, crushed by YHWH’s wrath so that their blood splashes His garments, expressing the violence and completeness of judgment.

deliberation: I considered if ‘day/year’ are simply temporal or symbolic, and whether ‘in my heart’ is anthropomorphic. The main figure is anthropomorphic: YHWH depicted with a ‘heart’ harboring a scheduled ‘day/year’ of vengeance/redemption.

instances.hebrew_text: כִּי יוֹם נָקָם בְּלִבִּי וּשְׁנַת גְּאוּלַי בָּאָה
instances.english_text: For a day of vengeance was in My heart, and My year of redemption arrived.
target: God’s inner resolve and timing for judgment and salvation
vehicle: a human heart harboring a marked ‘day’ and ‘year’ for action
human inner life and calendar time
ground: concealed intention awaiting its appointed moment
posture: emphasis on God’s deliberate, long-held purpose
instances.explanation: God is pictured as having a ‘heart’ where a specific day and year for vengeance and redemption are kept, using human inner-life and calendar imagery to depict divine resolve and appointed timing.

deliberation: I checked if ‘arm’ is literal or a stock figure for power, and whether wrath ‘supporting’ God is literal. ‘Arm’ is a metonymy for divine power; wrath is personified as a helper that upholds God’s action.

instances.english_text: So My own arm wrought the triumph for Me
ground: ability to act and exert force to accomplish a task
posture: insistence that salvation comes from God alone
instances.explanation: God’s ‘arm’ stands metonymically for His power, using a human body part as a figure for divine saving strength.

instances.english_text: and My rage—it was My aid/support.
target: the internal driving force behind God’s judgment
vehicle: a supporter or ally who props someone up
ground: providing needed support or energy for decisive action
posture: portraying divine wrath as actively energizing judgment
instances.explanation: God’s wrath is personified/metaphorically depicted as a supporter that ‘upholds’ Him, highlighting wrath as the empowering force for His judging activity.

deliberation: I separated three different images: trampling peoples, making them drunk in wrath, and casting their ‘glory/strength’ to the ground. Each uses a different figurative domain for judgment.

instances.english_text: I trampled peoples in My anger
target: God’s subjugation and destruction of nations
ground: complete overpowering and humiliation under superior force
posture: graphic depiction of God’s victorious judgment
instances.explanation: The peoples are depicted as something underfoot that God tramples, portraying judgment as crushing and humiliating defeat.

instances.english_text: I made them drunk with My rage
target: the disorienting effect of God’s judgment on the nations
vehicle: a person becoming drunk from strong drink
ground: loss of control, staggering, confusion brought on by an overpowering influence
posture: stressing the incapacitating force of divine wrath
instances.explanation: God’s wrath is likened to an intoxicant that makes the nations ‘drunk’, emphasizing how judgment overwhelms and disorients them.

instances.english_text: and I hurled their glory/strength down to the earth.
target: the downfall of the nations’ power and prestige
vehicle: something being cast down from height to the ground
ground: moving from high to low symbolizes humiliation and loss of status
posture: assertion of complete humiliation of the enemies
instances.explanation: The nations’ ‘glory/strength’ is cast down to the earth, using spatial descent as a metaphor and metonymy for humiliation and loss of power.

deliberation: I considered if ‘house of Israel’ is purely genealogical or figurative. It functions as a standard metonymy/collective metaphor, ‘house’ for the people descended from Israel.

instances.english_text: to the House of Israel
vehicle: a household or ‘house’ as a unit
ground: a ‘house’ stands for the family or lineage associated with it
posture: liturgical recollection of God’s goodness to His covenant family
instances.explanation: ‘House of Israel’ uses the image of a household to represent the entire people descended from Israel.

deliberation: I asked whether ‘children’ (בָּנִים) is biological or relationally figurative here. In apposition to ‘my people,’ it functions as a covenantal metaphor of God as parent and Israel as children expected to be faithful.

instances.english_text: Surely they are My people, children who will not play false
target: Israel’s covenant relationship and expected loyalty to YHWH
vehicle: children in a family bound to honor their parent
ground: expected trust, loyalty, and obedience from dependents to a caring authority
posture: recounting God’s hopeful expectation of filial faithfulness
instances.explanation: Israel is metaphorically called God’s ‘children,’ highlighting a familial covenant in which they are expected not to lie or be disloyal to Him.

deliberation: I noted three distinct figures: (1) God sharing Israel’s distress (anthropopathic), (2) ‘angel of his presence’ using ‘face’ as metonymy for God Himself, and (3) God lifting and carrying Israel, a parental/shepherding metaphor.

instances.english_text: In all their troubles [He] was troubled
target: God’s empathetic involvement with Israel’s suffering
vehicle: a person who feels distress when others suffer
ground: sharing in another’s pain as a sign of deep relational solidarity
posture: affirmation of God’s compassionate identification with His people
instances.explanation: God is described as being ‘troubled’ in all their trouble, an anthropopathic metaphor portraying Him as emotionally sharing Israel’s distress.

instances.english_text: and the angel of His presence delivered them
target: God Himself acting to save, mediated or manifested
vehicle: His ‘face/presence’ as represented by an angelic messenger
ground: God’s ‘face’ stands for His personal presence; the angel represents that presence in action
posture: highlighting the immediacy of God’s personal involvement in their salvation
instances.explanation: ‘Angel of His presence’ uses ‘face’ as metonymy for the personal presence of God, embodied in a messenger who saves them.

instances.english_text: He raised them and carried them all the days of old
target: God’s protective and sustaining care for Israel
vehicle: someone lifting and carrying another (parent, shepherd, rescuer)
ground: providing support, bearing burdens, and ensuring safety through carrying
posture: celebratory remembrance of God’s tender, sustained care
instances.explanation: God is pictured as physically lifting and carrying His people, a metaphor that evokes parental or shepherd-like care over time.

deliberation: I checked whether ‘Holy Spirit’ is given human emotions. The key figure is that Israel ‘grieved’ God’s holy spirit—personifying the spirit as capable of emotional pain.

instances.english_text: and they grieved His holy spirit
target: the effect of Israel’s rebellion on their relationship with God’s Spirit
vehicle: a person whose feelings are hurt or grieved
ground: relational offense causes emotional pain, signaling broken fellowship
posture: underscoring the seriousness of rebellion as personally wounding God
instances.explanation: The Holy Spirit is personified as one who can be grieved, using human emotional language to depict the relational rupture caused by Israel’s rebellion.

deliberation: I focused on ‘shepherd of his flock’ applied to Moses/leadership. This is classic leadership-as-shepherd metaphor; other elements are more historical than figurative.

instances.english_text: along with the shepherd of this flock
target: Moses (and possibly other leaders) guiding Israel
vehicle: a shepherd caring for and guiding a flock of sheep
ground: guidance, protection, and responsibility for vulnerable dependents
posture: nostalgic recall of God-provided leadership during the Exodus
instances.explanation: Moses is portrayed as a ‘shepherd’ and Israel as God’s ‘flock,’ using pastoral imagery to describe leadership and care.

deliberation: I noted the ‘glorious arm’ at Moses’ right hand as a body-part metonymy for power, and ‘to make for Himself an everlasting name’ where ‘name’ stands for reputation.

instances.english_text: whose glorious arm was made to march at the right hand of Moses
target: God’s powerful, glorious assistance to Moses
vehicle: an arm manifesting strength and honor
body part as symbol of strength
ground: an arm exercises strength and accomplishes work
posture: crediting Israel’s deliverance to God’s own power
instances.explanation: God’s ‘arm’ is a metonymy for His powerful action, here described as ‘glorious’ and accompanying Moses.

instances.english_text: to make for Himself a name for all time
ground: a name stands for the honor and reputation associated with it
posture: asserting that God’s acts in history serve to establish His renown
instances.explanation: ‘Name’ is used metonymically for God’s reputation; making an ‘everlasting name’ means securing enduring fame and honor.

deliberation: I observed the explicit כְּ (‘as’) marking a simile: God’s leading Israel ‘through the deeps’ is likened to a horse in the desert that does not stumble.

instances.hebrew_text: מוֹלִיכָם בַּתְּהֹמוֹת כַּסּוּס בַּמִּדְבָּר לֹא יִכָּשֵׁלוּ
instances.english_text: Who led them through the deeps so that they did not stumble—like a horse in a desert
target: Israel’s safe passage through dangerous waters
vehicle: a surefooted horse moving in the desert without stumbling
ground: smooth, unhindered, secure movement through potentially treacherous terrain
posture: praising the steadiness of God’s guidance
instances.explanation: Israel’s being led through the ‘deeps’ is compared to a horse that does not stumble in the wilderness, stressing the secure, unhindered nature of God’s guidance.

deliberation: I distinguished the explicit simile ‘like cattle descending to the plain’ from the broader shepherding/leading metaphor: God’s Spirit giving rest and ‘leading’ the people as a shepherd.

instances.english_text: Like a beast descending to the plain
target: Israel’s movement into a place of rest and safety
vehicle: cattle going down into a fertile valley
ground: moving into a level, nourishing, restful place
posture: evoking a pastoral picture of God’s care
instances.explanation: Israel’s transition to rest is compared to cattle going down into a valley, suggesting ease, safety, and provision.

instances.hebrew_text: רוּחַ יְהוָה תְּנִיחֶנּוּ כֵּן נִהַגְתָּ עַמְּךָ
instances.english_text: the spirit of the LORD gave them rest; thus did You shepherd/lead Your people
target: God’s guidance and granting of rest to His people
vehicle: a shepherd leading a flock to rest and pasture
ground: guiding dependents to places of safety and rest, ensuring their well-being
posture: praising God as a gentle, competent leader of His people
instances.explanation: The LORD’s Spirit is portrayed as giving rest and God as ‘leading’ His people, extending the shepherd metaphor of caring guidance.

deliberation: I noted several anthropomorphisms, especially ‘the yearning of Your bowels and Your mercies’ being ‘withheld.’ This uses bodily organs as the seat of compassion and pictures that compassion as being restrained.

instances.english_text: Your yearning and Your love [lit. tumult of Your innards and Your compassions] are being withheld from me
target: God’s compassion and affection toward His people
vehicle: inner organs (bowels) stirred and then restrained
ground: strong inner stirring symbolizes intense compassion, and restraining it signifies refraining from acting in mercy
posture: lamenting the apparent withdrawal of God’s felt compassion
instances.explanation: God’s compassion is portrayed in anthropomorphic terms as inner organs in tumult, yet ‘held back,’ expressing the sense that His mercy is presently restrained.

deliberation: I focused on two figures: (1) calling God ‘our Father’ as a relational metaphor and (2) ‘Your name is our Redeemer’ where ‘name’ stands metonymically for God’s identity/role as Redeemer.

instances.english_text: Surely You are our Father ... You, O LORD, are our Father
target: YHWH’s covenant relationship, authority, and care toward Israel
vehicle: a human father’s relationship to children
ground: origin, care, protection, discipline, and identity given by a father
posture: appeal to God’s paternal responsibility and affection
instances.explanation: God is addressed as ‘our Father,’ a metaphor that frames Israel’s relationship with Him in terms of familial care and authority, especially when human patriarchs would not recognize them.

instances.english_text: From of old, Your name is ‘Our Redeemer’
target: God’s identity and role as Redeemer
vehicle: God’s ‘name’ as the label by which He is known
ground: a name stands for the person’s recognized character and role
posture: reminding God of His long-established role as Redeemer
instances.explanation: ‘Your name is Our Redeemer’ uses ‘name’ metonymically to refer to God’s established identity and reputation as the one who redeems His people.

deliberation: I identified two standard conceptual metaphors: (1) ‘ways’ as moral paths from which Israel wanders, and (2) the ‘hardening of the heart’ as a figure for inner stubbornness or insensitivity to God.

instances.english_text: Why, O LORD, do You make us stray from Your ways?
target: Israel’s deviation from God’s will and commandments
vehicle: wandering off from a path or road
travel along and away from a way
ground: deviating from an established path corresponds to disobedience or loss of right direction
posture: lamenting spiritual misdirection and attributing it paradoxically to God
instances.explanation: God’s ‘ways’ are metaphorical paths representing His will; to ‘stray’ from them is to deviate morally/spiritually.

instances.english_text: You harden our heart from revering You
target: Israel’s inner disposition toward God, especially lack of reverence
vehicle: a heart becoming hard and unyielding
ground: hardness suggests resistance, insensitivity, and unwillingness to be shaped
posture: describing spiritual callousness in concrete, bodily terms
instances.explanation: The ‘heart’ is portrayed as being hardened, a metaphor for becoming resistant and insensitive to God’s fear and will.

deliberation: I checked ‘trampled Your sanctuary’ and the brief possession language to see if they are metaphoric. Given the context of conquest and defilement, this can be read quite literally—enemies physically trampling the temple—so I did not treat it as clearly figurative.

I identified multiple figures: (1) being ‘called by Your name’ as metonymy for covenant identity, (2) tearing the heavens as a dramatic metaphor for divine intervention, and (3) mountains quaking/melting before God as hyperbolic theophany imagery.

instances.english_text: Your name was never called upon them
target: belonging to YHWH as His covenant people
vehicle: having God’s ‘name’ called upon a group
ground: bearing someone’s name signifies ownership, relationship, and representation
posture: contrasting Israel’s identity with that of other nations
instances.explanation: ‘Your name called upon them’ is a metonymy for being under YHWH’s rule and ownership; saying it never happened defines those outsiders as non-covenantal.

instances.english_text: If only You would tear open the heavens and come down
target: a dramatic, unmistakable intervention of God into history
vehicle: ripping the heavens like a curtain and descending through
ground: tearing a barrier symbolizes breaking through distance and inaccessibility
posture: urgent longing for a conspicuous theophany
instances.explanation: God’s intervention is pictured as physically ripping open the sky and coming down, a vivid metaphor and mild hyperbole for a manifest theophany.

instances.english_text: so that mountains would quake [melt/flow] before You
target: the overwhelming effect of God’s presence on creation and human powers
vehicle: mountains shaking or flowing away in God’s presence
ground: immovable things being shaken or dissolved signifies irresistible power and awe
posture: heightening the imagined impact of God’s coming
instances.explanation: Mountains ‘quaking/melting’ before God is hyperbolic metaphorical language expressing how utterly overwhelming His manifested presence would be.
